{"step_by_step_thinking": "The citric acid cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle or the tricarboxylic acid cycle, is a series of chemical reactions used by all aerobic organisms to release stored energy. The cycle ends with the regeneration of oxaloacetic acid, ready to combine with another acetyl-CoA molecule, and begin the cycle again. Glutamic acid and nitric acid are not involved in this cycle.", "answer_choice": "A"}
